name: 陳儀
objective:
Course description: This course is intended as an introduction to some of the key concepts and ideas in Chinese Philosophy. Through reading of some of the most influential texts of main thinkers, students will develop a general understanding of Chinese philosophy and how these may relate to contemporary life. This course will not assume any previous knowledge in the area. All reading and discussions are in English.
Requirements: The course is conducted in English and demands active participation. Students are expected to contribute actively to class meetings by posing questions and by responding to the questions and comments of other students based on the material in lectures and readings. Students are asked to establish small groups and to conduct analysis on related project and give an oral presentations before the final exam.
（全英語授課）
schedule:
Week 1  Course Introduction: The Spirit of Chinese Philosophy
Week 2  Confucius
Week 3  Confucius
Week 4  Mencius
Week 5  Mencius
Week 6  Xunzi
Week 7  Tomb Sweeping Day
Week 8  Mozi
Week 9  Group Meeting (Students need to set work schedule and management plan for an oral presentations of group projects.)
Week 10  The logicians
Week 11  Laozi and Zhuangzi
Week 12  Neo-Taoism
Week 13  The revival of Confucianism
Week 14  The Neo-Confucianism
Week 15  The Neo-Confucianism
Week 16  Presentations of Group Projects
Week 17  Presentations of Group Projects
Week 18  Final examination
scorePolicy:
Class Participation: 40%
Group Assignments (oral presentation and PowerPoint slides): 40%
Final Exam: 20%
materials:
JeeLoo Liu (2006). An Introduction to Chinese Philosophy: From Ancient Philosophy to Chinese Buddhism, Blackwell Publishing
Lily Zhang (2011). Thirty Chapters on the History of Chinese Philosophy, Le Jin Books.
Wing-Tsit Chan (1973). A Source Book in Chinese Philosophy, 4th Printing, Princeton University.
I will be selecting some of the primary literatures in Chinese Philosophy as a self-made teaching material. Translations of some of the texts can also be found online on the Chinese Text Project: https://ctext.org/
